posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9630617
>I see a LOT of people talk about how it isn't worth playing today except for nostalgia but I have zero nostalgia for anything Atari and I'm a big fan. Here's some of my favorite 2600 exclusives:

To be fair, there is some merit to that. That's around the era of the console gaming crash, because you had zero quality control for games publishing back then (Nintendo was one of the first to introduce a quality checking system with their Seal of Approval), leading to numerous copy-cat games and an infinite number of below-shovelware titles. On PC it was a bit different, because PC's back then were expensive, and almost exclusively owned and operated by adults, and if you were developing a game for it, you knew that your core audience was going to potentially be more limited and they were going to be more discerning with their purchases.

For consoles though, it was a free-for-all. You had companies and individuals who never knew what a video game was until the year some of those consoles came out, developing video games for them.

Most console games from then are rightfully lost forever to the trash bin of history, and the ones that are left are still mostly shovelware. There's maybe 100 decent titles spread across the Colecovision/Atari 2600/Intellivision/Atari 5200. Of those decent titles, which ones are actually good? Maybe 25.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9632503
>everyone gave a shit about hi scores on consoles

No, they gave a shit about high scores in arcades. High scores on consoles were looked at as being pedantic, which is why you quickly saw the formation of goal-oriented gaming instead of score-oriented gaming, a clear and obvious development to any even tangentially aware of video gaming history.

You can see the individual evolution of console games from 1977 up to 1985 and how they gradually phased out high-scores. The progression of space-shooters from the likes of Asteroids in 1979, up to Elite in 1984, is one of the most obvious progressions of game design one can see.

>>9632456
>because you had zero quality control for games publishing back then (Nintendo was one of the first to introduce a quality checking system with their Seal of Approval), leading to numerous copy-cat games and an infinite number of below-shovelware titles.
That doesn't make the games devoid of enjoyment, even if they're bad. It really comes down to whether or not you can engage with the gameplay conventions of games of that era, most of which are the result of hardware limitations. There are plenty of shit games, sure, but what is or isn't considered shit is pretty subjective when it comes to early 8-bit stuff. I see people defend the 2600 port of Pac-Man in normiebook groups all the time. A lot of people just don't really find satisfaction in the simplistic gameplay. The vast majority of 2600 titles are screen-clear games where you're chasing high scores. If you have a decent understanding of why the games of that day were designed how they were and the history of the hardware behind them it provides a lot more context which makes them enjoyable even if you don't have any nostalgia around them.

>For consoles though, it was a free-for-all. You had companies and individuals who never knew what a video game was until the year some of those consoles came out, developing video games for them.
yes this is true, there was once a time that video games didn't exist.

>There's maybe 100 decent titles spread across the Colecovision/Atari 2600/Intellivision/Atari 5200
Purely out of spite I'm going to list you 100 good games from those consoles in my next post.

>>9632035
>>9632009
First game is definitely a rough experience, I wouldn't recommend it if you are the kind of person that drops a game at the first sign of frustration. Second one is much more solid and a great starting point. The third game is basically the second one with more polish but it pays the price with a kind of mediocre plot and some very annoying exploration elements that tried to focus on some new mechanics. Fourth game is extremely divisive and probably makes a terrible starting point independently of how you feel about it. Fifth one is really solid but also has a very unique gimmick so not a great place to start. 6th one is the most solid over all but it's also where the series ends and unlike other megaman games, the story isn't afraid of actually finishing so it'll be a shame if you actually want to experience the story of the games.

My recommendation is to skip 1 and start with 2. The first game has an important plot point that every other game spoils right away but it's not one you get to enjoy as a plot twist anyway because it's just dropped on you out of nowhere with almost no build up so it doesn't matter how you find out about it. If you really like BN2, you can go back to BN1 right away and decide if you want to play it before moving on to the rest of the series.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Keep in mind this is anecdotal, but growing up, the pretty universal opinion my peers had was that Sonic Adventure 2 was better than Sonic Adventure. I never put much thought into it until I replayed both games recently on the DC. There are a few monstrous flaws SA2 has that SA1 does not have, and for those reasons alone I wonder why I still see people online claiming that 2 is markedly better than 1. Even on /vr/ I've seen people say SA1 is outright bad and that SA2 is the best Sonic game.

1. The structure of the original is a lot better than the sequel. Both SA1 and SA2 feature radically different gameplay styles, speed levels, shooting levels, exploration levels, etc. But in SA1, you're given a lot more control over the kinds of levels you want to play, whereas in SA2, if, for example, you just want to play Sonic's levels, you're held hostage and forced to play through Tails' and Knuckles' stages in between speed stages. I think there's even, multiple times, instances where you play as Tails->Tails->Knuckles or some combination like that during the hero story. I think SA1's approach, separating the character stories, was a much more reasonable option.

2. SA1 tends to get the little nuanced things right. For example, in SA1 when you play as Knuckles, your emerald radar can detect all three emerald shards at once in a level, if you're close enough to them. Whereas in SA2, pretty much purely for the sake of trying to pad the game out, your radar can only detect a single shard at a time. It's a pretty cheesy and transparent way to make Knuckles' levels not seem so short.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
3. The original Sonic Adventure felt more like the Genesis titles in terms of level design. Similarly to those games, there are tons of little shortcuts you can take throughout most of Sonic's stages thanks to how potent his spinball is in the game. SA2 unfortunately neutered the shit out of the spinball in that regard, and the levels are a lot less shortcut friendly and just generally less interesting.

4. I'll also mention variety, although that's not really an objective positive or negative. I think Tails' levels are more interesting in SA1 since the shooting levels already exist with E-102 Gamma. That being said Amy's levels are a bit booty so whether or not you like the additional gameplay variety is up to personal taste. I thought Big's stages were inoffensive.

5. Same goes for the overworld. I don't think that's a net positive or negative, it's more of a personal taste thing. I liked it, thought it made the game feel more cohesive and a little more fleshed out.

Things like preferring one soundtrack over the other all are subjective, so there's no point in discussing that. But for the reasons listed above, comparing each game side by side, SA1 is just the more well designed title.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Only five is a narrow fucking selection, but I think these have some variety to them, have some good appeal at a glance, and are mostly easy to get into, even if some of them are actually pretty hard. I am espousing playing both SNES and Genesis games, as their libraries have some of the finest games of their time periods, both Nintendo and Sega were on their absolute top game here IMO.

SNES:
>Super Metroid
>Chrono Trigger
>Final Fight 3
>Wild Guns
>Kirby's Dream Course

Genesis:
>True Lies
>Shining Force
>Splatterhouse 3
>Zero Wing
>Zero Tolerance

There's not really anything like SM on the Genesis, likewise, SNES doesn't have anything which is even remotely like ZT, which is about as ambitious as you can make a first person corridor shooter for the given hardware. The amount of fine detail is legitimately impressive, struggling ports of classic Doom and Wolf3D don't really measure up.
Likewise, SNES doesn't do shootemups nearly as well as the Genesis (and none with a soundtrack as good as ZW's), but while there are some good RPGs in the latter's library, there's nothing there which is anywhere near close to the scope and ambition of CT.
KDC is pretty distinct, there's probably some golf games on Genesis, but the isometric 3D together with the powerups and imaginative courses is novel. Under the deceptive cutesy exterior, it's actually quite a difficult game.

FF3 isn't mindblowing or anything, but it's an enjoyable brawler, SOR is arguably better, but it's very much in the same vein, being about fighting punks in urban environments, you can get that on both systems. Meanwhile, Splatterhouse isn't maybe anything special in mechanics or gameplay, but the detailed gore and horror it features is something which the SNES has no counterpart to at all.
TL has a SNES version which is 99% identical, but I just threw it in because it's an inviting topdown shooter. I'm sure Genesis has a counterpart to WG which I'm not thinking of, but just the same I'm throwing that in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Is this the most ambitious game series of the 1980s? I became aware of it from recently playing the Famicom version (Daiva Story 6) on Nintendo Switch Online. It was a fun and unique little game, but I don't know Japanese so I had no idea what was going on storywise. In the process of looking up more information I stumbled on the actual development history of the whole series and found it fascinating.
>7 games
>7 platforms
>each tells a part of a single overlapping story from a different protagonist's perspective
>each has sci-fi interplanetary 4X gameplay
>but also turn-based tactical space ship battles
>but also sidescrolling action platform-shooter levels
>each gameplay layer influences the next
>all developed simultaneously
>all planned for simultaneous release
>all designed to make maximum use of each platform's capabilities so no one would feel short-changed by an inferior port
>development was so intense that the director of the game went temporarily blind from stress
Is anyone else familiar with this? It seems the other versions were a lot more complex gameplay-wise than the Famicom one. I might give the MSX one a try since it has a fan translation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's an ambitious project, for their dedication to making sure each machine received a quality conversion.

Multiple platforms though? That's not really unusual for hit software of the era.

Ys 1 for instance launched on 5 different platforms within the 3 month launch window (PC 88, Sharp X1, PC 98, FM-7, MSX2).

And then also received: Famicom, Master System, PC Engine, Apple IIGS and DOS ports before the 80's were up. That's a total of 10 different platforms in roughly 2 years (87-89).

So from my understanding: Daiva devs (T&E Soft) were in touch with what going in the Japanese gaming scene and wanted to best utilize how spread out software was. Which makes sense is they already developed mega-hit Hydlide and were kings of that particular golden age. Why not go all out? Develop a similar game, with each new platform offering a distinct piece of the narrative. People got to share stories and mention what they got out of the game. Pretty cool. No shortcuts either.

>>9633894
The reason all the doors were locked in the RPD was because of the outbreak (that's why there were boards on all the doors in RE3 as well, Marvin and Elliot's group took them down before the events of 2).
The rooms tied to the keys also make sense for the most part
>File Room (confidential files there)
>break room and library (no reason for non-staff personnel to go back there, even going as far as the STARS Office is iffy)
>Evidence room (obvious)
>Interrogation Room (only used by interrogation officers)
>Press Room (important room for press events)
>Night watch hall (obvious reasons, also leads to the morgue, breaker room, and detention lock up)
Everything past that is Umbrella shit that would be kept heavily locked up.
As for stuff like the Chief's office being incredibly out of the way, there's not much reason to see the chief on a regular basis. Most stuff would probably be called in through his secretary. All the shit that matters for public use (Offices and interrogation rooms) are on the first floor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9634140
>RE1
The mansion is a cover and is designed to kill people. Puzzle solutions only exist because they had watchmen and some staff living there, and they had set paths leading to the actual courtyard and lab entrance. When you reach the Guardhouse, you only explore a small portion of it but it's just locked by simple dorm keys (as it's a dorm for staff staying overnight), with only specific areas being locked up. The caves are weird only because you have to explore more of it than any staff typically would (and the reason for it being so hidden is because they were conducting illegal research), and most staff likely came in via helicopter (where you have immediate access to the lab).
>RE2
The RPD is likely never that locked up and only was due to the outbreak. That's it. It's a fairly standard design since all the offices and the interrogation rooms are easy to access. People mention the lock ups being past a lot of important rooms, but they aren't. They're next to the parking garage, which is where any detainees would first be taken to.
>RE3
It's mostly just keys or making stuff work properly, only truly weird bits come in at the City Hall where you need jewels to open the door.
>CV
Alfred is obsessed with his sister, Alexia is obsessed with family lineage. The parts of their facility their employees need to access are accessible, but their personal stuff (the route to Alfred's castle, Alfred's torture chamber, Alexia's hidden mansion lab) are more esoteric to find.
>Zero
The Training Facility needed to keep the illegal research separate from the training part of the facility.
>Zero

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes its a very tedious game. Having to replay the Syrian tombs level like three times was bad enough, but to then have to do the whole underground eldritch city section TWICE almost back to back was pure insanity. Until you get the invisibility and sanity regeneration runes, most of the gameplay is just having your sanity instantly sapped by the same boring zombies, watching the finishing blow animation six times to fill your meter back up, then walking into the next room where it immediately goes back down and you do it all over again. The story is barebones and not very interesting either. It's just Augustus tricking people throughout time, then they pick up the book, explore some ruins then die, then you play as Alex, rinse and repeat. Really nothing of substance happens for what is otherwise an interesting premise.

I know it had a troubled development but it really is a very unfinished game that doesn't live up to its potential. I have a feeling it's cult status stems from the fact that:

>It's an adult oriented game in a console library with not many adult games (REmake, RE4, Killer 7 and thats about it)
>Miyamoto had some minor amount of input
>The journalists and YouTubers who played it back then probably haven't played it since and look back with rose tinted glasses. Still hype it up regardless and zoomers buy into it as le hidden gem.

I've played a lot of survival horror games and Eternal Darkness is a solid 6/10 at best. Very disappointing because I actually like lovecraft stuff and the first few hours of the game. Don't force yourself to finish it like I did, its not worth it.

WTF is this awful take. No shit if you treat it like an action-adventure game like Tomb Raider you aren't going to like how slow and plodding the combat and meters are. Absolutely nothing about it is remotely unfinished. The big appeal other than the incredible amount of attention and detail that goes into the continuous timeline are the insanity effects. Yes some of them are silly gimmicks like a message saying your controller is unplugged, but others are subtle and establish atmosphere like walls slowly looking more and more like skulls depending on how empty your sanity meter is, or the sound effects add just a few more creepy ones, etc.

you can win with the first car you buy though so if you crash you can just restart the game and try again straight away

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625662
>okay having more than a standard memory card is decent I guess but who the fuck needs gigabytes of save file storage for a playstation

Nobody, it's just that PS1 memcards were so small that even the smallest MicroSD card from 10 years ago will have enough space for thousands.

>for what purpose? Oh wow I don't need to take out the SD card, as if you'd ever need to do that anyway when it's going to have 9001x as much storage space as you'd ever need for save files anyway

Just for easy backup/transferring of saves without having to take out the MicroSD card every time. I don't really care about this feature that much to be honest, but the microcontroller it runs on has built in WiFi so no real reason not to enable it. It's built off an ESP32.

>for what purpose? Just seems like a meme
So you can actually see which of your "9001x" cards you currently have selected instead of just blindly cycling through them

>Okay so it can't boot games, it just uh... allows you to have virtual memory cards? Who gives a fuck

... people who play games on a PS1? If you have a lot of games those cards can fill up fast, and even if you have a lot of cards you need the keep track of which cards have which game's saves on them. The ODE integration makes it so it automatically creates a virtual card for each game and auto-switches to it when you boot a game off your ODE.

>>9625680
Ah yes, I remember that thing. Had the N64 version as well.... have fun running it on a modern PC. It would be cheaper and easier to just use the PS3 memcard adapter and homebrew software to read PS1 memcards on a PC instead, at least that thing is USB and there is modern homebrew software for it.

>>9626385
Might be a different revision. I had a mix of official and unofficial cards and all I saw was socketed. But yes you would need a game bit, but that's true of opening up pretty much anything Nintendo.

And yes, the N64's saving is a mess. Depending on the game it could save to the cart, but also could save to a memory card... you would think then that the memorycard was nonvolatile memory like the PS1... or even to BOTH. Only some of the earliest N64 games that saved to the cart used battery-backed SRAM while just about all later games used one of multiple implementations of different kinds of nonvolatile memory.... while the memorycards were battery-backed. What an idiotic mess. On top of that there was no built-in memory card management application like the PS1 and Saturn had, you had to hold Start while booting up a game that supported memory cards... and there was no standard or guidelines on how to design said manager so they varied wildly in features and what they could or could not do. From only being able to delete saves on controller 1, to supporting copying and/or moving saves, to supporting all 4 controllers, to supporting hot-swapping of cards/controllers or not. It was very un-Nintendo of Nintendo actually to not have an iron grip on exactly what the manager should look and act like. Compare that to the DS where the WiFi configuration application is not built into the DS itself but on the cart of any game that supports WiFi.... which is hard to even realize since Nintendo forced everyone ot use the EXACT same implementation down to it's appearance.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9626406
>oled screens

A tiny OLED screen like that is literally cheaper than an LCD screen. And how else do you suggest people be able to know which memorycard they have currently selected on a device that can have thousands?

>wifi support

As explained, that's built into the microcontroller it runs off of. They even lowered the price (It used to be $50) by ditching the FPGA and exclusively running the card off the WiFi microcontroller, which also increased compatibility.

>xstation bonuses are all memes

That's litearlly 100% software. It cost $0 to implement.

>Now, if all that bloat were stripped out

Then it would be at most $2 less if you removed the OLED screen, which then would require you to just guess which of your thousands of memorycards you had currently selected.

You can't remove the WiFi because yet again, the entire thing runs off the microcontroller of an already very cheap and budget WiFi board. It would literally cost more to put a non-WiFi CPU with memory in there.

And the Xstation support literally costs nothing because it's all software.

It's already as stripped down as you can reasonably get. A simple extreme budget WiFi controller is already capable of a lot on it's own, no need to add anything extra that increases the cost. They already did exactly what you wanted, they stripped out the FPGA and it lowered the price. Specifically, it was the ESP32-S3 revision of the board that allowed them to strip out the FPGA and lower the cost.

The ESP32 itself would cost nearly $10. So if you want to build your own OLED-less blind equivalent for $10, here is an ESP32-S3 board: https://www.amazon.com/ESP32-S3-Bluetooth-Internet-Development-ESP32-S3-DevKit/dp/B0BPP28ZFB/

Or just the bare chip if you are good enough to use that: https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/espressif-systems/ESP32-S3-WROOM-1-N16/16162647

Have fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9632962
There is a Dreamcast one being worked on.

As for Saturn, that would be extremely messy since it used internal storage. There would be no way to have an "infinite" memorycard like this that lets you swap to different banks of storage without having to solder a few dozen points to the Saturn itself, and it would also likely require modification of the shell to to add buttons/screens to swap the storage.

Best best for Saturn would be memorycard-like carts, which already exist. Of course, those require you to manually copy saves to/from them outside of the handful of games that supported saving directly to them, but with it's default save method being internal there is no real way around that.

SegaCD was the same but nobody seems to care about that. I have no idea what the situation with the "RAM" cartridges on that was like, if games were supposed to all have support for directly saving to it instead of internal or if it was the same situation as the Saturn where you mostly just manually moved saves to/from the cart.

A PS2 should be easy to do, if it doesn't exist already. It's memorycards were essentially a DRMed memory stick. You would need to break the (now 23 years old) DRM, but after that, a standard SD card would do the job... though you would need a bit of additional hardware if you want to have built-in card switching or WiFi or anything like that. I know there there were also unofficial memorycards that were larger than 8MB and the PS2 could read them... but I have no idea if there was compatibility issues with those since Sony never officially made any cards larger than 8MB. (Regardless, a modern one would need to split your SDcard into virtual 8MB cards anyway since nowadays the smallest SDcard you can by is 16GB... and I doubt the PS2 can handle that)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614145
if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
in EU you should:

>put your starting base in Europe or North Africa which gives you the maximum # of funding countries covered
>start research on laser weapons immediately
>construct your base so the entrance lift is a choke point if the aliens raid it
>play sniper-spotter--don't shoot aliens with the guy who spotted them as he could get reaction shotted, use someone else
>never do nighttime crashed UFOs, there's no reason to not wait for morning

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>officers are morale boosters, not necessarily better soldiers--if they die in battle your squad will suffer a higher morale loss
>aliens will try to target your officers ahead of the grunts
>soldiers who get wounded and are out of action for longer than 15 days should be sacked and replaced by a new guy
>normally you will always want to use auto fire with ranged weapons
>ranged weapons in EU have damage roll of 0-200%, whereas TFTD uses 50-150%

i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing so you don't have to worry about bringing them down, and if you're worried about night missions you can usually wait a few hours before actually sending your skyranger in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9631206
>i'm not nearly as experienced with tftd so i can't really provide input on it
It's generally similar with the following important differences

>aliens will do shipping route attacks starting in April--these can have any alien race on them
>artifact sites will start appearing in July--these are always a Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew, and you cannot duck out of them due to a massive point penalty (-1000 points for failing to complete the mission, -3000 for ignoring it).
>the game will generate 12 artifact sites, one for each region of the globe
>colonies are always Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew in part 1 and Lobstermen in part 2, but the race that constructed the colony will send supply ships to it
>on lower difficulty settings you will get more port/island attacks and fewer shipping route/artifact sites
>in infiltration missions, none of the alien infiltration fleet lands--until you get advanced craft weapons you will not be able to shoot down most of the USOs
>the TFTD terror ship (Battleship) has more powerful weapons than the battleship (Dreadnought) so while you could easily shoot down a EU Terror Ship with two Interceptors+Avalanche missiles, it's extremely risky (but still possible) to attempt it in TFTD--since it also never lands, the only way to fight one is to shoot it down
>in base defense missions, up to 5 aliens will spawn inside your base
>the Barracuda has shorter range than Interceptor and can't fly as far before running out of fuel

another little pointer is that when fighting landed or crashed UFOs there's a certain probability that aliens will spawn inside the ship or outside of it. this depends on their rank, but generally:

>soldier 50% chance
>engineer 30% chance
>medic 30% chance
>navigator 10% chance
>leader/commander 0% chance (they're always inside on the bridge)

this is why sometimes you find a UFO jammed full of aliens like a clown car and other times it's only got a few inside

Russia is partially in Europe and part in Siberia but the main reason why Siberia doesn't get infiltration missions was purely for technical reasons--because the region has only one city in it and there'd be nowhere else for the infiltration fleet to land.

>>9631206
>i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing

https://www.ufopaedia.org/index.php/MISSIONS.DAT

Most UFOs on most missions land except during retaliation. Small scouts only land during base construction or harvest missions (small scout #1 on harvest missions lands, #2 doesn't). The first terror ship on terror missions does not land either. Shooting a UFO down of course may spawn a retaliation mission, which is a 50% chance of occuring either in the region the shootdown was in or the region where the X-COM craft that shot it down is based. If a retaliation scout passes over your base, it may become revealed to the aliens, and the odds go up the more facilities the base has.

If you shoot down the Battleship attacking the base with an X-COM craft, or they don't find your base at all, the retaliation mission ends. If the aliens do attack and you beat them in a base defense mission, the retaliation mission is immediately restarted with a new Small Scout and they'll keep going for it until they fail to find your base or you shoot down the incoming Battleship. if you shoot it down with base defense weapons it produces the infamous bug with endlessly attacking Battleships.

>>9631610
>people forget that the Bond franchise was on life support after the two Dalton films sucked all the fun out of it.
I really don't get people who say this.

I fucking love Roger Moore's stint, his movies are my favorite, and generally he's who I think of when I hear someone say James Bond. They're weird and have this sense of levity and slightly fantastical wonder which captivated me even as a kid, but they were also serious in tone, the stakes and motivations always felt real, even when it got mildly out of hand with Moonraker, the tension was there, and there was some grim violence to back it.

Dalton's 007 is like an opposite to Moore's, and that's why I really love those movies. This James Bond is more grounded and cynical, more dark and brutal, he's far more cold blooded towards his much more cruel enemies, he doesn't hesitate to kill, and there's just far less levity and goofy fun. Some who love Moore's movies hate that, but I love it, BECAUSE it's very different, and because it's closer to the books, straying from that isn't inherently a huge problem, but there's a value in capturing it.
The Living Daylights was probably the most 'realistic' movie yet in the series, with a spy plot which was actually very grounded and well planned, featuring fight choreography which felt quite real, yet also very elaborate and creative, the opening fight with the assassin in the kitchen is incredible in setup and execution, by far the best brawl in the series. Yet it still has that 007 charm, it still has the far out gadgets, it still has the gorgeous girl, it still has the lively music, and the scheming mastermind.

As much as I love Moore's 007, that was a long stint, and it couldn't go on forever, moreover the change in direction was ultimately very good, A View To A Kill was already nudging towards that, and I love that movie for it. Sometimes a series of works alters its direction, and sometimes that doesn't have to be bad.

>>9631610
>They had a lot riding on Goldeneye, and if it had sucked there’d have been no more Bond movies.
Goldeneye is comparatively toned down in 'edge' and brutality to The Living Daylights and License To Kill, and while I think Pierce Brosnan does an excellent job, I also think that as 007 he's just kinda 'so-so' overall. It does however keep up the same grounded tone of the Dalton ones, more so even, but the movie would probably have been very similar if they had gotten Dalton to do it as his last one. The way the brutality was comparatively toned down was likely in regards to the response of many fans to the previous two, and it'd most likely have been the case even with him as the star.

>people were still doing Goldeneye tournaments in the late 2000s. Could you say that about Doom or Quake more than a decade after their releases?
Yeah, actually, there was still some competitive Doom and Quake gameplay by 2003 and 2006, far less than during their heights of course, but that was also the case with Goldeneye, which didn't have much for netplay options for some time. You didn't strictly need to physically travel for competitive Doom and Quake multiplayer.

>>9634784
>In short: bc Bond is a fantasy for men.
Yes?

>A secret agent who lives an exciting and dangerous life but still has charm, culture, knows every social grace, and routinely bags beautiful women (all for country, of course). Bond viewers don’t want a realistic spy film, they want the fantasy; the Dalton ones removed too much of the fantasy element from the character.
Nigger, how are they NOT fantasy? Milkbottle bombs, knockout gas keyrings, a literal ghetto blaster, a super car with skis, a jet thruster, seeking missiles, and tirepopping lasers, which can also cut a car in half and has a self-destruct function. The Living Daylights alone is full of pretty standard fare 007 gadgetry (License To Kill has its own share). Then you've got shit like riding a cello down a snowy mountain, a staged political assassination, a ridiculous as fuck automated sliding door for a shop being used for a kill, and hanging on to a net of cargo out the back of a plane while struggling to fight off a super assassin. Let's not forget the weirdo fuck arms smuggler who fancies himself a military genius, or the incredible and wild fight scene in the beginning of the movie.

I don't know about you, but none of that shit sounds mild, or easygoing, or like common things in most people's daily lives, this is still a very extreme exaggeration of real life espionage. Sounds like it would make an exciting adventure though.

>Brosnan‘s take seems to project that much better than Dalton’s. Nobody’s ever going to equal Connery, which Moore understood.
Fucking DALTON understood that, he rejected earlier offers because he thought he was too young at the time, but also because he could never match Connery, an opinion he still holds. He himself may have wished for the slightly more grounded angle with the grimmer 007, because that's closer to the books which he was already a fan of, but he was hardly the main creative drive behind the movies he was in.

usually low on fat. fat describes extraneous shit that doesn't add much tangible to the game but may enhance things like settings and atmosphere but ultimately isn't much to actually play. Yeah, easiest way is to edit your save file. The best way of editing Pokemon in any games is with PKHeX:

>>9621925
>It can take on a physical form, manifesting as weapons, armor, or sentient beings. The Maverick Virus behaves like an actual virus, spreading through physical space.
The Maverick Virus mutated from the Wily Virus, which was based on the Evil Energy that Wily found in Megaman 8.
According to Duo in MM8, the Evil Energy is actually a sapient alien substance that absorbs evil within robots minds and then multiplies as to infect more robots. Dr. Light found out that performing a full analysis of it was impossible (much like Zero's system). An entity made out of pure energy is an interesting concept since it can be a power source, be translated into electrical signals (and be transmitted as a virus) and even be converted into mass. Due to this method of replication, the original source can only be harnessed by beings of pure evil. The Wily virus made from it probably works in the same manner, "absorbing" Zero's destructive programming when he fought Sigma and had the migraines, and then spreading to Sigma and the rest of the reploids. Only someone who's pure evil could have it in their system and not die from it (like Wily in robot form).

That's why the Maverick Virus is so unorthodox and can do shit normal computer viruses can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the plot of X4 put plainly.

Repliforce was created to supplant the need to combat Mavericks due to the growing number of riots and rebellions perpetrated by Sigma and the virus, which the Hunters could barely control on their own, as evidenced in the past three X games. Repliforce's purpose was shown to be inefficient, and the Hunters were itching for a reason to disband them. Sigma noticed this, and began orchestrating the Sky Lagoon incident.

Magma Dragoon was a Maverick Hunter and prideful warrior who's always envied X's superior fighting abilities, believing the latter always hend back whenever they sparred during training sessions. This grudge he harbored against X allowed Sigma to convince him to sabotage Sky Lagoon and become a Maverick, all so he could force X to have a real fight with him, no holds barred. Still, Dragoon's motivation to betray the Maverick Hunters wasn't enough to cause the Repliforce war, as that would come later.

When the Sky Lagoon crashes, X and Zero find evidence of Repliforce presence in the rubble. They also find Colonel investigating the crash site, who claims to be looking for his sister Iris. The Hunters immediately demand him to surrender his weapons and follow them to the Hunter base for questioning (which often ends in imprisonment or decommission for Reploids, as someone has to take the fall until the real culprits are found, if ever. After all, the Maverick virus scare is a good enough prerogative to let the Hunters point fingers at just about anyone despite their own general ineffectiveness). The Maverick Hunters immediately grow suspicious when he refuses - the image of the second-in-command of Repliforce being detained would ruin public opinion on Repliforce and basically guarantee its dissolution through vox populi.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625775
As far as the game dialogue is concerned, yes. The war happens because Colonel himself is too proud to accept the accusation as legitimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625818
The Hunters then demand General to disband the Repliforce and turn himself in for inquiry. Years of experience fighting Mavericks fueled the Hunters' concern that Repliforce could become dangerous, should they become infected by the Maverick Virus or grow strong enough to overpower the Hunters themselves.

The Hunters had a solid reason to be worried, but their authoritarian "do as we say or else" attitude was a big fucking insult to a man like General. Before the incident took place, Sigma warned him that this would happen sooner or later, as human beings were growing wary of armed Reploids running around (though General did not recognize Sigma during their meeting, since everyone thought he was dead for good). Sending a Repliforce representative to talk it out with the Hunters wouldn't work, since the Hunters wouldn't even give Colonel, General's right hand man, the time of day. General then decided that Repliforce should simply leave planet Earth and build a reploid colony in a space station. It wasn't a declaration of war so much as a "you don't trust us, so we're leaving" statement. The Hunters, of course, regarded their disobedience as Maverick behavior, and then the fighting began. The "Final Weapon" was originally the space station they wanted to move to, and was only turned into an actual weapon after the Hunters started going after Repliforce.

Even after the war begins, Repliforce officers like Jet Singray were shown evacuating the civilians before carrying out orders to destroy certain locations. Storm Owl's brigade was attacked by the Hunters, including X, who found himself acting just how Sigma wanted him to, when he denied Owl's accusation that the Hunters were corrupt, before executing him with a charged shot to the face.

Meanwhile, Double was sent by Sigma to Hunter base as to disrupt the flow of information and prevent any chance of peace accords between Repliforce and the Maverick Hunters from happening. And so you have Megaman X4.

>>9628239
Putting it into order it goes like this:
>Evil Energy -> Wily Virus (EE + robot reprogramming algorithm) -> Maverick Virus (Wily Virus optimized to explot Reploid design flaws) -> Sigma Virus (Maverick Virus fused with Sigma's digitized AI at the end of X1) -> Zero Virus (Sigma Virus fused with the virus smuggled by Dynamo into the Eurasia space colony and Zero's AI) -> Nightmare Virus (Zero Virus + DNA Program successfully reverse-engineered by Gate) -> Copy Chip (DNA Program of Sigma and many other old Reploids rendered inert and implemented into New Gen Reploids as to make use of the abilities it grants users)
It may sound silly in a work of fiction, but do remember how many strains of COVID we've gotten in like 3 years.
Putting this into perspective, EE being a sapient entitity does lend to the idea that it keeps consuming hosts and evolving much like a virus, jumping from robot to robot, system to system, mechaniloid to mechaniloid, iteration to iteration. Given the X series' overarching theme of robot free will, it does seem like the virus itself is acting on its own free will in a very twisted way, by rending others of their own.
If Wily turning himself into a cyborg holds true or at least plausible, the virus may have even taken over him. After all, his real body was never found. It may even hint at the reason why X and Zero are not allowed to go near the locations where their capsules were found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9629926
Mostly this, but I would actually say the control scheme of the original is the only reason to play it at this point. Many shit on it because it's so unique and has a pretty deep learning curve until you're used to it. But once you are, no other game is like it. You really feel the difference in the weapons, swinging back and forth with the greatsword versus stabbing up and down with the lance. I understand the people who didn't like it, but to me it's sublime and the thing I missed most about the game on it's sequels.

I am a monster hunter super fan though, it's probably my favorite series of games ever. I maxed the clock at 999 hours on the original long, long before I stopped playing and other than Tri on the Wii and the World/Rise games I've put at least several hundred hours into every one.

Playing the original now would be kind of sad because the online was such a major component but it's still an awesome game regardless and the offline game is quite a complete experience in it's own right. If you like it there's plenty more Monster Hunter out there to jump into including Generations Ultimate which is basically the best the series has ever been and still has a decent player base.

That said, the player bases as in all online games are always a little funny. One thing we still joke about is the first time I actually got my PS2 hooked up online. I almost always use greatsword, but happened to have a hammer on me when I came into the hub. I was HR1 so an online newbie, and the first thing said was "hey welcome to MH! Hammers suck btw" because there was an early (wrong impression that they did) but neither happened to notice the hammer I had was the Breathcore which is the most powerful one in the game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9635143
1>3>2

1: Classic game, combines both challenge & fun. Literally 3D Super Metroid. Only weak point is his story, where in retrospective there's not much to say except chozo lores you casually find here and there. It's just
>Retrieve or get new weapons, explore.
A really old school Metroid, but with new gameplay, but i like it.
3: A refreshing and ingenious breakaway from "Samus alone her entire mission" formula. More humans, and actual presence/interraction with the galactic federation we hear about since Fusion, while keeping the good old basis. Feels like a good budget sci-fi flick. In some way i enjoy MP3 more than the others even though i grew up with MP1 and love that gave more than any other games.
2: Despite the godsent return of the screw attack and fun weapons like the annihilator, or the echo visor or the god tier light suit, this is a more boring, and tedious reboot of Metroid Prime 1. Feels like a Metroid Prime 1 "The Lost Levels". If want to play Metroid Prime 1, i just play Metroid Prime 1 insteead of this poorly inspired copycat. Its only strong point is the kind of original story MP1 was lacking.


Also... WHERE IS METROID PRIME HUNTERS? Amazing Metroid, despite being the weakest Metroid Prime.

>I tried several games, all of them boot and run fine but with no sound
Ok you're not the same guy as the OP. Your problem is apparently the console itself; the audio somehow isn't getting from the sound chip to the mixer circuit (also likely a bad trace). Another problem that often happens with SNESes is the power jack getting loose. I have a GPM-02 that otherwise works normally but it has that issue and you have to wiggle around the power cable to get it to work.

So I absolutely buy the theory that there was some definite cost cutting on SNESes (both the console itself and the carts) compared with the NES, and probably because the hardware and games cost so much more to make.

>>9624769
They're different games.

Puyo 2 is the standard and the best version of it is on the Saturn, although Super Remix on the SNES is pretty good too.

N64 has two Puyo games, Sun and Yon. The former is decent and the second best game in the series though some people bitch about the Sun Puyo RNG. The latter killed Puyo though, adding character-specific abilities was a mistake and fucks up the balance.

And then lastly there's the original Puyo, which was reskinned into Mean Bean Machine and Kirby's Avalance. There's no real reason to play this version anymore since there's no offset rule which makes the gameplay far deeper and more exciting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Both are great
The GCN library is way the fuck deeper than the N64
It was also an era where Nintendo was doing a bunch of weird and interesting things with their IPs, so you got stuff like Metroid Prime, Mario Strikers, Luigi's Mansion, WarioWare and then new IPs like Pikmin and Eternal Darkness
On top of that you got Animal Crossing and Fire Emblem representation in the west, and significantly better third party support over the N64.

So to me it's like, yeah if I picked the top 5 games of the N64 to go head to head with the top 5 games from the GCN, the N64 would probably come out on top. But the sheer weight of the GCN's library pretty handily puts it on top over the N64 overall.

It's funny though I've been a Gamecube supporter since it launched, I bought FE: Path of Radiance and Paper Mario TTYD on launch, I was one of the poor bastards who had to wait an extra month to play Twilight Princess because I wasn't super interested in the Wii. So take that all into account when I say: I think the recent deification of the Gamecube is a massive over correction. It was an awesome console at the time and I don't think it deserved to be as eclipsed by the PS2 as it was, but holy FUCK do people put it up on a pedestal these days.

>>9633014
I got SM64 Christmas 96 and OoT in fall of 98 with my allowance, so yes I was there. I'm not saying they're bad games, I'm saying from a more objective perspective they aren't revolutionary. Virtually no games copied the SM64 camera frankly a good thing, everyone was copying the Quake and Tomb Raider cameras instead and things evolved from there. Z-targeting in OoT was a nice evolution for melee, but that's all it was. Z-targeting without movement was already in Megaman Legends, and Z-targeting with movement was already in Tomb Raider, so all OoT did was adapt it for melee with relative direction inputs. Again, a nice evolution, but obviously not revolutionary.

N64 was my favorite console since 1996. However I’ve been playing the Gamecube a lot since last year and noticed that a lot of the N64 games I loved have Gamecube sequels and ports, some better some worse. Let’s look at the list of the best N64 games:

>Ocarina of Time
- Ported, with a bonus master quest version
>Majora’s Mask
- Ported
>Mario Kart 64
- Sequel (Double Dash) is better
> Super Smash Bros
- Sequel (Melee) is better
>Goldeneye & Perfect Dark
- Timesplitters 2 is almost as good, plus you get Timesplitters 3 and you also get 5 James Bond games
>Rogue Squadron
- sequel is better
>Super Mario 64
- sequel is not as good, good enough though
>San Francisco Rush
- ported

Anyways, you pretty much get an at least decent followup, if not better version, of every great N64 game.

On top of this you have, with a Gameboy Player, access to 3 Gameboy generations, and through that ports of the best NES and SNES games (and that’s not even counting the compilations)

And on too of all that, you get RE4 and Metroid Prime 1&2

I can’t believe I’m saying this, but the Gamecube really is the better console. The amount of Zelda, Resident Evil, Sonic, Mega Man, and Mario games you can play on that thing is just mind blowing

>>9635436
There's a Japanese version of Dragon's Trap for the Master System (Monster World II) that was never properly released. Remnants of it exist in the English version like the title screen and soundtrack, but not enough for a complete functional version.
It was released in Japanese, but on other platforms: ported to the Game Gear with heavily stripped down gameplay, and ported to the PC Engine with different protagonists and overall story. Even rereleases of Dragon's Trap used those versions instead of the lost Monster World II (JP) Master System version.

That version is included here.

There's reason to believe it's legit, because the English version of Wonder Boy in Monster Land (Arcade) was similarly lost and then uncovered for a 2010 release. I want to add it to my romset for completion's sake.

>>9634730
2 was a refinement over 1.
If you discount the addition of a password system and E-Tanks to restore health when you're in trouble, they made important changes.
>Boss patterns are more manageable, but are still challenging whilst somewhat fair (though Air Man cannot be survived indefinitely as some patterns are undodgeable)
>Different levels provide different mobility items, making runs from multiple starting points more viable (lots of players need Item 2 to finish Heat Man's stage)
>The score system was culled, leaving more room for item drops from enemies to restore health, weapon energy, or extra lives (the drop rate was reasonably generous, too)
>Level design was less unfair, fewer precise jumps that need you to jump at the last pixel of footing

There was also just that the Metal Blades were too good of a weapon, It was effective against most enemies and bosses, and had very low energy usage on top of being spammable, AND was eight-directional to boot.

>>9635060
Not many, only experts and great connoisseurs of the retro games (or /vr/ as we like to call it on the 'chans), know of this obscure game development and publishing house, or as we like to call it on the 'chans, a hidden gem.
To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Atari's games. The gameplay is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of theoretical physics most of the mechanics will go over a typical viewer's head. There's also Atari's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation- his personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these jokes, to realise that they're not just funny- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Atari games truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in Escape from the Planet of the Robot Monsters, which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev's Russian epic Fathers and Sons. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Mark Stephen Pierce's genius wit unfolds itself on their CRT screens. What fools.. how I pity them.

And yes, by the way, i DO have a Rick & Morty tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand. Nothin personnel kid

>>9628014
It's a shame, because all of the good parts of 2 are the concepts.
The museum is great, and Dan being awakened by a guy fucking with magic is cool. The mummy girlfriend is hot and the Ripper stuff was a very interesting idea. The vampire manor, the freak show, and the boxing match are all awesome ideas for levels, and Kew is kind of a follow-up to Pumpkin Gorge. But there's obviously problems.
The streets outside of the museum is an ugly slog after the museum, Wulfrom is kind of annoying to actually play at the start, the boxing match is incredibly frustrating, and Kew is straight-up annoying. The hub is alright, but the projector feels like a lame copout for a level select when the first had that atmospheric map. We went from largely having on character in Dan to having too many cartoony people with the ghost and the professor.
Medievil was fun to play, but it was a whole package of atmosphere, art direction, music, and gameplay. 2 just doesn't add up the same.
And I bought the comic that was their supposed idea for 3. It was like half an idea. It wasn't even enough for a sub 100 page count book.

>>9630558
What I like about MediEvil 1 is, it has multiple characters, but it very much feels like Dan's journey and ultimately he's facing it alone along the way. He gets help from other characters, but only in singular instances. MediEvil 2 diminishes this a little by having a full cast along the way that don't have much mystique behind them (something that bothered me is how much you see Winston in each level but he's absent from every cutscene despite being Kift's assistant, it felt very inconsistent). The projector-based hub was always disappointing to me, I think it would have been a lot more impressive if they kept the world map but made it a map of London instead. If I had to push further, I'd rather it not have been London at all, I think it would have been much more interesting if they invented a fictional Victorian-esque city to set the game in, because it always took me out of the game how it went from a fictional land like Gallowmere to a real city like London.

I have to add too that MediEvil 2 is almost punishing if you don't unlock a new weapon on each level. The first time I played it as a kid, I missed the chalices from the third level onwards (not necessarily a bad thing making finding them a puzzle in itself) but as a result fighting everything from the freakshow onwards was a struggle, especially up to Kew Gardens when I still only had the short sword. Conversely, having a new weapon just to deal with enemies on the next stage doesn't feel very exciting. If you play the first game using only the starting weapons, you can still make decent progress without feeling like you're hitting a wall constantly. I don't think 2 is truly a bad game, it's tight in a lot of areas but very disappointing in others.

>>9634768
An hour and a half is the length of a movie. It's not unreasonable to expect someone (specifically, children) to sit down and play for that long.
Retro games usually weren't intended to be one-and-done experiences like most games today. Beating the game meant getting so good at the game that you could finish it in a reasonable amount of time.
And if you still want to complain, you can always use save states or play the director's cut version that adds passwords.
